items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob Nuñez, SuperintendentSUBJECT:Possible Parcel Tax MeasureIn light of the current and continuing State fiscal crisis and in an effort to preserve and maintain current levels of teachers, staffing, education programs and other resources, Administration recommends that the Governing Board consider a parcel tax measure.  Parcel taxes require approval at an election by at least 2/3 of those voting on the measure.  Proceeds of parcel taxes can be used for general fund purposes (operational expenses) or as may be limited in any ballot measure.  While ballot measures for school district parcel taxes typically focus on “programs,” the proceeds can also can be spent on teacher salaries, materials, equipment, and so on, provided the ballot measure is worded correctly.  FISCAL IMPACT:To be DeterminedFUNDING SOURCE:N/ARECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize and direct the Administration to study the feasibility of placing a parcel tax on the ballot and report its recommendation to the Board.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Dan Moser, Associate Superintendent of Instruction and Human RelationsSUBJECT:Authorization to Issue Notice of Remedy to MACSA Academia Calmecac Charter School.The District is concerned that MACSA Academia Calmecac charter school may have committed material violations of its charter and is seeking authority to issue a Notice of Remedy.  Specifically, the District has learned that MACSA Academia Calmecac is substantially in arrears in STS/PERS contributions for its charter school employees.  The charter school is currently under investigation by the County Office of Education in connection with the charter school’s finances and the management of its fiscal affairs.The California Charter Schools Act of 1992 requires the authorizing agency of a charter school to monitor and oversee the charter and further provides that a charter may be revoked by the authorizing agency if it finds that the charter has, among other actions, committed a material violation of any of the conditions, standards or procedures set forth in its charter, failed to meet generally accepted accounting principles, engaged in fiscal mismanagement, and/or violated any provision of the law.  Education Code 47607(d) requires that prior to revocation, the charter granting agency notify the charter school of any violation of the foregoing and give the charter school a reasonable opportunity to remedy the violations(s), unless the authority determines, in writing that the violation(s) constitutes a severe and imminent threat to the health or safety of the pupils.  If the charter fails to remedy a violation within the period specified, the chartering agency may commence revocation of the charter in accordance with the procedures prescribed in the Education Code.FISCAL IMPACT:NoneFUNDING SOURCE:NoneRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize the Superintendent to issue a Notice To Remedy pursuant to Education Code 47607 to MACSA Academia Calmecac Charter School.

Schools are ensuring alignment of the Board’s Priority Areas, the Single Plan for Student Achievement, and the WASC Self-Study.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Dan Moser, Associate Superintendent of Instruction and Human RelationsSUBJECT:Declaration of Need for Fully Qualified Educators as NeededIn July 1994, the Commission on Teacher Credentialing changed the process for emergency credentialing.  Prior to that time, districts were required to issue individual statements of need for each applicant.  The applicant, in turn, would take the declaration of need to the county office of education for the issuance of an emergency credential. This applies to the following credentials or authorizations: Emergency CLAD, BCLAD, Resource Specialist, Library Media, Clinical or Rehabilitative Permits.Now, the Commission issues a permit to an individual who qualifies for an emergency based on the district’s Declaration of Need.  This Declaration, approved by the local Board of Trustees, is submitted to the Commission once a year.  Emergency permits, although originally used primarily to staff partial assignments and special education, now help fill the fully credentialed teacher gap created by class size reduction and statewide teacher shortage.  Every attempt is being made to hire credentialed teachers before considering people on emergency permits.  Attached is the Commission on Teacher Credentialing form titled Declaration of Need for Fully Qualified Educators.  Pursuant to direction from the county office of education’s credential’s office, the district is over estimating the number of permits it might require in order to cover any unanticipated needs that might occur during the course of the 2009-2010 school year.FISCAL IMPACT: As per salary scheduleFUNDING SOURCE: General, Special Education and Adult Education fundsRECOMMENDATION: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Declaration of Need for Fully Qualified Educators

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Dan Moser, Associate Superintendent of Instruction and Human RelationsSUBJECT:Approve CAHSEE Local Waivers for Special Education StudentsEducation Code Section 60851 states that students who take one or both parts of the CAHSEE with a modification and receive the equivalent of a passing score are eligible for the waiver request process.  At the request of the student’s parent or guardian, a school principal must submit to the local school governing board a request for a waiver of the requirement to pass the part(s) of the CAHSEE on which a modification was used and the equivalent of a passing score was earned.  For the local board to waive the CAHSEE requirement, the principal must certify to the local board that the pupil has all of the following:An individualized education program adopted pursuant to the federal Individuals with Disabilities Education Act or a plan adopted pursuant to Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 that requires the accommodations or modifications to be provided to the pupil when taking the high school exit examination.Sufficient high school level coursework either satisfactorily completed or in progress in a high school level curriculum sufficient to have attained the skills and knowledge otherwise needed to pass the high school exit examination.An individual score report for the pupil showing that the pupil has received the equivalent of a passing score on the high school exit examination while using a modification that fundamentally alters what the high school exit examination measures as determined by the State Board of Education.The waivers were requested by the school site administration on behalf of the students’ parents.The recommended waivers meet the aforementioned criteria delineated in Education Code Section 60851: Student A	Student B	Student C	Student D	Student E	Student FStudent G	Student H	Student I	Student J	Student K	Student LStudent M	Student N	Student O	Student P	Student Q	Student RStudent S	Student T	Student U	Student V	Student W	Student XStudent Y	Student Z	Student A2	Student B2	Student C2	Student D2Student E2	 FISCAL IMPACT:NoneFUNDING SOURCE:NoneRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the recommended waivers.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Dan Moser, Associate Superintendent of Instruction and Human RelationsSUBJECT:Approve New Courses:  Carpentry I and IIThe Instructional Policies Committee (IPC) has reviewed the Carpentry 1 and Carpentry 2 courses.  These courses were piloted during the 2008-2009 school year.  The course descriptions are included for your review.  Carpentry I: Carpentry I is an extensive hands on training in a project based setting utilizing modernized basic and finish carpentry resources. This course prepares students to master skills necessary for careers in the construction industry. Students will learn construction safety, site preparation, first aid, measurements and materials, costing, planning, adhesives, fasteners, and will develop a variety of projects using hand and machine tools. This course will prepare students to progress into higher level trades courses.Carpentry II: Carpentry II is an extensive hands on training in a project based setting utilizing modernized basic and finish carpentry resources. This course prepares students to master skills necessary for careers in the construction industry. Students will learn to master construction tools; understand principles of construction, framing, measurements and materials costing, residential plumbing, residential wiring, interior finishing, and develop blue print reading skills. This course will prepare students to progress into higher level trades courses and will emphasis a career in construction overview.FISCAL IMPACT:NoneFUNDING SOURCE:NoneRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the above courses.

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Alan Garofalo, Associate Superintendent of Student Services and FacilitiesSUBJECT:Approve Change Order #1 for W. C. Overfelt High School Phase IV New Science Building Increment II ProjectContractor:  BCI Builders, Inc. The W. C. Overfelt High School Phase IV New Science Building Increment II Project is complete. The following change order is submitted to the Board of Trustees for approval.Bid #Purchase Order #DSA #Project #B-07-07-0880317601-108787G-040-011 Item #DescriptionReasonAmount1Certain walls were framed incorrectly by BCI, resulting in rework by SASCO.  BCI is providing a credit to match Sasco's additional costs.  See PCO 019.1.Unforeseen Condition($892.00)2Submittal review comments added drawers and a backsplash, which were not originally called for in the plans.Requested by Architect$3,937.003ASI #005 added additional enclosure panels, toe-kicks, and plastic laminate aprons at all classrooms, which were not originally called for in plans.Requested by Architect$8,589.004Additional wall demolition at the Building G restrooms was performed in order to accommodate unforeseen plumbing changes.Unforeseen Condition$651.005During removal of canopy posts, it was discovered that additional canopy plaster required abatement.Unforeseen Condition$2,118.006Additional framing was required for the niche added to conceal the backflow preventer from view and potential vandalism.Requested by Architect$394.007Upon removing existing tile and grout in Building G restrooms, it was discovered that the slab was depressed and needed to be floated to provide proper finish floor elevation.Unforeseen Condition$1,939.008Size of wood nailer increased from 2x12 to 3x12 in order to accommodate Structural Engineer's change to the hanger types.  This change represents the net increase in material cost.Conditions Warranted$2,978.009Size of wood nailer increased from 2x12 to 3x12 in order to accommodate Structural Engineer's change to the hanger types.  This change represents the cost to remove and replace a portion of the 2x12 material already installed.  There are no "double costs" between this PCO and PCO 35.Conditions Warranted$1,734.0010During wall demolition in Bldg. G restrooms it was discovered that there was no sheetrock draftstop in the existing wall.  Draftstop was provided in order to comply with current code.Conditions Warranted$253.0011Provide wall insulation at Bldg. G restrooms.  It was discovered that existing walls in Bldg. G restrooms were not insulated and no new insulation was called for in the contract documents.Conditions Warranted$1,430.0012Additional plumbing wall was added as a result of changes to Bldg. G restroom layout necessary to meet certain ADA clearances.Requested by Architect$2,144.0013Learning Walls were added at each classroom at the request of the District.  Change includes added casework, framing, and drywall.  As a result of added Learning Walls, 10 marker boards did not have to be installed.  Marker boards were delivered to the District.Requested by Owner$86,828.0014Additional soffit framing was required as referenced in SSI #012.  This framing was not clearly depicted in the contract documents.Unforeseen Condition$21,253.0015The addition of learning walls removed an access point into each classroom soffit.  Plywood catwalks were installed in all classroom soffits to facilitate safe access across each soffit.Conditions Warranted$1,341.0016An additional projector screen was requested in each classroom.  This cost reflects the additional framing and drywall for pockets in each classroom soffit.Requested by Owner$17,486.0017Additional electrical equipment was installed in order to accommodate the added audio/visual system per the District's request.Requested by Owner$28,195.0018The attachment at ledgers was changed from 16D penny nails to 4 1/2" and 6" SDS screws per RFI 052.  The required 1-hour fire rating at classroom walls could not be maintained with the attachment shown on plans.Conditions Warranted$5,893.0019Curtain walls at Lines 1, 6, and A were framed down per RFI 116.1.  There were no framing details on the plans for the roof structure to top of windows.Conditions Warranted$6,607.0020Adequate framing details at lines B and 1 for storefronts were not provided on the plans, and PSL beams were installed upon direction from the design team.Requested by Architect$8,516.0021A furring strip was installed at the line 5 soffit and line 4 windows, which was not noted on the plans but is required to properly attach metal flashing.Conditions Warranted$654.0022Metal straps were installed at all doorways having only one anchor bolt, as directed by RFI 029 and not clearly depicted on the plans.Conditions Warranted$368.0023Interior wall at Line 4 was furred out to accommodate electrical conduit.  The original design left the conduit fully exposed.Conditions Warranted$5,714.0024A new glulam beam with hangers was installed at the canopy off Line M per the response to RFI 112.  The glulam was not part of the original design and was added by the structural engineer via RFI 112.Requested by Architect$1,516.0025Five extra sheets of 3/4 CDX fire-rated plywood were installed at the request of the District in order to accommodate devices in the data room.Requested by Owner$720.0026RFI 092 added new structural framing to resolve a connection that was not clearly detailed on the plans.Conditions Warranted$4,475.0027Due to unforeseen low subgrade, additional baserock was required for walkways.Conditions Warranted$8,614.0028Concrete pavers were installed to provide a transition from limit of work to existing walkway on North side of building.Conditions Warranted$12,813.0029Exterior door texture was ambiguous in the contract documents and the approved submittal.  BCI agreed to cover the cost of replacing doors, provided they were compensated for the labor to replace them.Conditions Warranted$2,272.0030Specified gate closers would not work in designed configuration.  The architect approved these alternative closers in RFI 151.1.Unforeseen Condition$193.0031Architectural punchlist requested that plastic laminate panels be added at fumehoods to hide exposed plumbing piping.Requested by Architect$588.0032Credit for deleted canopy framing at 0.5 Line.Conditions Warranted($1,554.00)33BCI floated and feathered all exposed drywall penetrations that received 3M fire-rated caulking at all fire-rated walls, as required to provide an acceptable appearance/finish as the areas in question are exposed in view.Unforeseen Condition$2,457.0034Original design was insufficient in providing support for pass-through windows.  Contractor proposed the addition of stainless steel U-channels in RFI 147, which was approved by the Architect.Conditions Warranted$3,354.0035Add sod and miscellaneous irrigation to complete landscape restoration at the East end of the building at the flagpole area.Conditions Warranted$5,115.0036Negotiated from contract.Requested by Owner($263,636.00)Original Contract Price:$2,875,000.00This Change Order: ($14,943.00)Revised Contract Amount:$2,860,057.00FISCAL IMPACT:($14,943.00)FUNDING SOURCE:Capital Facilities FundRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve change order # 1 for W. C. Overfelt High School Phase IV New Science Building Increment II Project (BCI Builders, Inc.).

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Alan Garofalo, Associate Superintendent of Student Services and FacilitiesSUBJECT:Approve Change Order #1 for W. C. Overfelt High School Phase IV New Science Building Increment II ProjectContractor:  Dolan Concrete Construction The W. C. Overfelt High School Phase IV New Science Building Increment II Project is complete. The following change order is submitted to the Board of Trustees for approval.Bid #Purchase Order #DSA #Project #B-13-07-0880202501-108787G-040-011 Item #DescriptionReasonAmount1Plans called 7" x 7" wood posts in 6" framed walls.  ASI #001 changed them to 6" x 6" steel columns to fit within the 6" wall cavities.  This change represents the cost to provide bolt templates, forming, and new anchor bolts.Requested by Architect$3,242.002Contractor was directed to overexcavate and recompact certain areas of the building footings in accordance with the recommendations of the Geotechnical Engineer due to unacceptable soil conditions at these locations.Conditions Warranted$8,391.003HD anchor rods were removed and reset with revised anchor bolts to accommodate required embedment per RFI 012.Conditions Warranted$1,012.004Vent piping for the neutralization tank could not be properly concealed in the building as originally designed.  Alternate routing was provided via RFI 057 which involved removing a portion of the existing slab and trenching through it.  This cost reflects patching back slab concrete.Conditions Warranted$994.005Anchor bolt locations conflicted with column footing reinforcement, which was not discovered until template installation had begun.  The anchor bolt layout was changed and templates were redrilled and reset.Unforeseen Condition$3,777.006Additional concrete was required due to unforeseen additional underslab plumbing and to provide concrete curbs for additional required wall framing.Unforeseen Condition$4,534.007Existing underground electrical vault and concrete column footings not noted in contract documents were removed as required.Unforeseen Condition$7,542.008Additional excavation was required due to conflicting size details of A-line column footings.Unforeseen Condition$588.009This credit reflects the cost of vertical curbs omitted at South of building to eliminate potential ponding.Requested by Architect($7,637.00)10This credit reflects the cost of deleted materials at the concrete expansion joints per RFI 130.1.Requested by Architect($3,150.00)11Existing canopy supports specified to be removed during Increment I demolition were left in place to eliminate the need for temporary shoring between the end of Increment I and start of Increment II, alleviating safety concerns.  Existing canopy columns were removed when new canopy columns were ready for installation.Conditions Warranted$1,880.0012The school requested that a paved pathway be added for access with the golf carts used on campus.  This cost represents the concrete portion of the pathway.Requested by Owner$3,840.0013Concrete collars not called for were required to prevent soil contact with the tube steel fence posts West of the building.  A continuous concrete mowband was provided as a cost-efficient alternative.Conditions Warranted$459.0014Demo, final grading, and replacement of damaged concrete and AC pavement were required near the bus turnaround.  This work was not listed in the original scope and provides an aesthetically pleasing transition from new to existing walkways.Conditions Warranted$20,509.0015 Existing stairs utilized for reroute of primary electrical feed on North side of building were patched to match adjacent new concrete.Conditions Warranted$856.0016Demo, final grading, and replacement of architectural concrete were required at the existing North canopy.  This work was not listed in the original scope and provides an aesthetically pleasing transition from new to existing walkways.  A credit for $4,435.00 was obtained from Cupertino Electric in Increment I for a portion of this work.Conditions Warranted$16,597.0017Dolan Concrete poured fence post footings on behalf of American Steel.  See PCO 111.2 for associated credit.Unforeseen Condition$1,221.0018DI elevation was raised 1' at East of building to account for conflict between Increment I and Increment II.Unforeseen Condition$2,913.0019Miscellaneous erosion control measures from Increment I not in Increment II scope were removed in preparation for irrigation and landscaping.Unforeseen Condition$9,698.0020Final grading was required in the South and West landscape areas and was not included in the original scope.Unforeseen Condition$3,911.0021Sidewalk subgrade was lowered at the Southeast corner of the building due to discrepancies between plan and field elevations.Conditions Warranted$2,660.0022Negotiated from contract.Requested by Owner($84,116.00)Original Contract Price:$797,909.00This Change Order: ($279.00)Revised Contract Amount:$797,630.00FISCAL IMPACT:($279.00)FUNDING SOURCE:Capital Facilities FundRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve change order # 1 for W. C. Overfelt High School Phase IV New Science Building Increment II Project (Dolan Concrete Construction).

The following change order is submitted to the Board of Trustees for approval.Bid #Purchase Order #DSA #Project #B-11-07-0880317501-108787G-040-011 Item #DescriptionReasonAmount1Roof walk pads were added as required per RFI 115 as none were shown or called for on the plans.Requested by Architect$6,386.002Lead flashings were installed on the canopy roof to accommodate the future installation of added security cameras and light fixtures along the underside of the canopy.Requested by Owner$2,604.003Negotiated from contract.Requested by Owner ($12,055.00)Original Contract Price:$144,242.00This Change Order: ($3,065.00)Revised Contract Amount:$141,177.00FISCAL IMPACT:($3,065.00)FUNDING SOURCE:Capital Facilities FundRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve change order # 1 for W. C. Overfelt High School Phase IV New Science Building Increment II Project (Reinhardt Roofing, Inc.).

items.item_details: EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICTTO:Board of TrusteesFROM:Bob NuĂąez, SuperintendentPREPARED BY:Alan Garofalo, Associate Superintendent of Student Services and FacilitiesSUBJECT:Approve Change Order #1 for W. C. Overfelt High School Phase IV New Science Building Increment II ProjectContractor:  Sasco Electric The W. C. Overfelt High School Phase IV New Science Building Increment II Project is complete. The following change order is submitted to the Board of Trustees for approval.Bid #Purchase Order #DSA #Project #B-08-07-0880313901-108787G-040-011 Item #DescriptionReasonAmount1Copper busses were not originally called out in the project documents but were added per ASI #003.Requested by Architect$651.002Additional field investigation and work required to ensure Bldg. G offices would not lose power during power shut-off to Bldg. G restrooms.Conditions Warranted$609.003Existing light on underside of canopy at library entrance was left nonfunctional after canopy demo in Increment 1.  Temporary light with photocell was provided throughout new canopy construction and was replaced with a new fixture upon completion.Conditions Warranted$2,394.004This is an internal change for miscellaneous rework by Sasco caused by BCI.  BCI is providing a credit to match Sasco's additional costs.  See PCO 019.2.Conditions Warranted$892.005Specified wiremold size at each ADA sink apron was changed due to a conflict with cabinet doors.Conditions Warranted$2,444.006Learning Walls were added at each classroom at the request of the District.  This change includes relocation of installed electrical devices and learning wall power location adjustments.Requested by Owner$3,312.007Wireless access points were relocated per RFI 080 due to conflicts with the windows in each classroom.Unforeseen Condition$2,083.008On demand hot water heaters, automatic flush valves, and additional GFI outlets not shown on electrical drawings were installed in the Building G restrooms.Unforeseen Condition$3,246.009Revised "ZA" light fixtures were provided per RFI 123.  Original light fixtures were not returnable and were delivered to the District.Requested by Architect$6,710.0010The IDF cabinet was relocated from floor level to ceiling level due to minimum height requirements.  A power receptacle utilizing the installed conduit was provided at the original IDF location for future use and convenience.Conditions Warranted$727.0011Some of the required fire dampers were not shown on the electrical drawings which were installed to accommodate the fire dampers shown.Requested by Architect$3,762.0012Lighting layout was revised in Rooms B109 and B110 due to an unforeseen conflict between T-bar grid and ductwork.Unforeseen Condition$2,989.0013Magnetic starters for mechanical equipment were provided by Sasco Electric for Hellwig Mechanical.  Hellwig provided a credit to the District for the starters.  See PCO 089.2.Conditions Warranted$874.0014Contractor cut roof penetrations, furnished sleepers, and installed conduit sleeves at the new canopy for future security camera installation.Requested by Owner$3,126.0015Additional conduit was provided to allow EF-15 relay to be controlled from a wall switch, which was not called for.Unforeseen Condition$1,149.0016Exhaust Fans 9 and 10 specified 120 Volt power but the specified VFDs required 480 Volt power.  The installed 120V power was removed and refed with 480V power.  It was agreed between BCC, the design team, and the trade contractors to split the cost three ways: 1/3 from the District, 1/3 from Hellwig Mechanical, and 1/3 from Sasco Electric.  Net result is District authorizes a PCO/change for 2/3 to Sasco and a credit for 1/3 from Hellwig for full and complete compensation to all.  Therefore $2,666.67 to Sasco and $1,333.33 from Hellwig.Conditions Warranted$2,666.0017Additional duplex receptacles were provided at the under counter DI water systems in Rooms B113 and B121, as there were no provisions on the plans for the required power.Unforeseen Condition$696.0018A phone jack and cabling were provided for the new teacher workroom telephone per the science department's concerns list.Requested by Owner$1,315.0019Water heater circuit in chemical prep room was upgraded to 30Amp to alleviate tripping of the circuit breakers.Conditions Warranted$898.0020This cost reflects labor rate increases and schedule impact over the duration of Increment II.Unforeseen Condition$14,980.0021Negotiated from contract.Requested by Owner ($63,000.00)Original Contract Price:$698,350.00This Change Order: ($7,477.00)Revised Contract Amount:$690,873.00FISCAL IMPACT:($7,477.00)FUNDING SOURCE:Capital Facilities FundRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve change order # 1 for W. C. Overfelt High School Phase IV New Science Building Increment II Project (Sasco Electric).

(Roldan Builders, Inc.)Bid #B-19-07-08Pursuant to the contract awarded by the Board of Trustees on April 17, 2008, Roldan Builders, Inc. has furnished all material and finished all labor for the completion of work related to James Lick, Yerba Buena and Piedmont Hills High Schools Restroom Modification Project.With the approval of the Board of Trustees, the attached Notice of Completion will be filed with the Santa Clara County Recorder’s Office as required by law.FISCAL IMPACT:$1,867,161.05FUNDING SOURCE:Capitol Facilities FundRECOMMENDATION:It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Notice of Completion for James Lick, Yerba Buena and Piedmont Hills High Schools Restroom Modification Project (Roldan Builders, Inc.).
